ansible/roles/mariadb/tasks/recover_clus.message:
why there is create: yes ?, we expect that gastate.dat exist in mariadb volume, otherwise we want ansible to fail.

If there is create: yes and grastate.dat not exist (for any reason), lineonfile will just create that file, which we don't want to.

From ansible doc for lineinfile

Used with state=present.
If specified, the file will be created if it does not already exist.
By default it will fail if the file is missing.

Maybe it will help if you can describe the issue, when grastate.dat is missing ?

Restore procedure states the following:
> Delete the old data files
this usually includes grastate.dat.
This task only runs on the bootstrap host, where we would expect grastate.dat to exist. If it doesn't exist, shouldn't that be an error?
Not on the bootstrap node though, right?
In disaster recovery scenario it does not exist - as it's not part of the backup.

Right; restore instructions could very well also include ``touch grastate.dat`` in the volumes, but I wanted to avoid that. I don't immediately see why do we want the following:

> we expect that gastate.dat exist in mariadb volume, otherwise we want ansible to fail.

If the file exists, Ansible is just continuing silently.

- import_tasks: register.yml

How? In https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla/+/843751 you say it leaves a broken endpoint on upgrade.

In general, I'd say that when we perform a config migration such as this, where possible and sensible, the upgrade should just handle it. That might mean a temporary tweak to the upgrade procedure that we revert on the next upgrade.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Should work fine as-is, or we can restore the memory request.

playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/boots.message: We can leave the memory request, that hasn't been an issue the way that CPUs are.

When kubernetes sees resource shortages, one of the criteria for which pods to evict is whether the pod is consuming more than its "requested" resources.  So if we ever got into a scenario where memory is tight, changing the request to 0 will make this pod more likely to be evicted.

That said, we should be protecting the platform pods from eviction in other ways and so I'm not sure this is actually an issue.  But in other platform pods we have left any memory requests alone.
I did that to keep consistency and avoid problems in the future but I don't exactly have any preference. Do you think we should revert that?
0 means leaving it for k8s to allocation cpu for the deployment? (BTW, what does original setting "100m" mean?)
With it set to 0, it will not be reserved any CPU time, but it will be able to "burst" to the CPU limit if there's no contention for the CPU.   100m means 100 milli-CPUs or 1/10 of a CPU.

Rabi. I think your concerns are valid. Too much info is sometimes more harmful then not enough. I know Kevin has minimized the output and in our test on real environment we only got about 8 duplicate warnings. The more important we caught the ones that would cause issues.
https://paste.opendev.org/show/b0VvoJ5SS0zCqT8r45jZ/

Would it put your mind at ease if they were somehow converted to Informational messages (but still keep them visible during the deployment)?
Hi Saravanan, thanks for the comments. From the field engineering perspective we generally see majority of the errors caused by the user defined/specified values. Thanks for reviewing.

The environment mentioned by Saravanan is provided in cli only. We don't expect users to change the in-tree environment files directly, rather override the parameters with a new environment files which overrides a specific parameter. As mentioned earlier these warnings can be nuisance and misleading in the future.
This will only analyze templates that the user specifies on the CLI, it will NOT recursively analyze all templates that are part of a given stack.
When there are multiple duplicate parameters it will also show the last value, rather than focussing on values, it is enough if warn about duplicate defintion than the values.

Thanks Kevin. That's correct. It's very common for the deployment engineers to unintentionally overwrite the parameters with duplicates. Especially when deploying complex architectures, where different components are going after the same parameters. Displaying the value of the duplicates allows to identify the wrong value instantly.

Correct it will only raise a warning for the current value and inform the user that a particular item was duplicated within their defined templates.

This does have the possibility to raise a lot of warnings, however, after discussing with the deployment engineers (as represented here in reviews) the output format and potential for lots of info to be present is exactly what they're looking for.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
So today if the race happens then the periodic update_available_resource call will just exit early without doing any update[1]. 

After the fix the periodic will succeed but some devices might have empty capabilities list which can result in that devices stop being considered as netdevs or vdpa devs. I'm concerned that this might lead to resource tracking inconsistencies. So I suggest to create some functional test in the libvirt functional env that simulates the race with this fix and shows that we don't end up in an inconsistent state after the race.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/4939318649650b60dd07d161b80909e70d0e093e/nova/compute/manager.py#L10134

OK it seem to be more complicated than that.

The pci_tracker once initialized does not care about the changes of the pci devices inventory during the update_available_resource() periodic. So if the compute is started without hitting the race in device caps then later races does not cause any issues in the pci inventory. 

In the other hand if the race happens in during compute startup when the pci tracker is initialized, then with the current patch some device will simply missing from the tracker as they will not have the any capabilities not even 'pci'. And this is not fixed by the periodic run as stated above.

Without this fix if the race happens at startup then the pci tracker will not be initialized but the compute will start. Then if the next periodic runs without the race then that will initialize the pci tracker properly.

So I think after this fix we can create situation where after a compute startup some pci device will missing from the tracker and the only way to fix that is to restart the compute (and hope that it will not race at that time).

// later 

/o\ now I realized that the whole race is about devices disappearing from libvirt perspective and the result of the race with the current fix is that we will not track the device that is disappeared. Now the whole thing make sense.

Could you please extend the comment in the code with some of this explanation (suggested inline there).

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: I have some concerns pci devices flipping between being a netdev (when no racing) then not being a netdev (when racing).
Keeping the -1 but just to add more explanation to the code comment. The fix itself make sense now.

Why not take advantage of the freeIPA need (for TLS-e), and use its embedded secret storage instead of adding some new services such as Vault?
Access Control List is possible, making the overall thing far, far better and easier to manage - that host can access this vault in freeIPA, while this other host cannot;
Using kerberos and a keytab on the hosts make the overall authentication process transparent.

That would require Castellan to support freeIPA backend, of course. But imho, this is the right way. If people want encrypted secrets, they more than probably want encrypted internal connections - meaning they already have freeIPA for the CA.

specs/yoga/secret_management.rst.message:
Looking at https://docs.openstack.org/security-guide/secrets-management/faq.html seems like barbican is the official tool to manage secrets in OpenStack. I see Castellan has support for both barbican and valut key managers. Can you please elaborate on the exact nature of the addtional work you mentioned?

Also, valut has MPL2 license which is little stricter than Apache. Have we considered that?
I am also curious what work would be required in Barbican or castellan to support this. Is there a bug/RFE that can be linked here?

The oslo work that was done was only ever tested against vault directly, rather than through castellan, so we'd have to spend some time testing to make sure it works.  

Its a little tricky too because there is a small chicken/egg problem.  That is barbican needs a credential to keystone to validate keystone tokens and get context data, but if keystone passwords are stored in the secret store behind barbican ...  I'm sure we can design around it, but it will take some work.
castellan is a library and not a secret store. It must be backed by a secret store such as barbican or vault.

Ack.  What if rephrase as ..

We do not expect there to be too much follow-on work required though, because
this spec encompasses the work to get tripleo to work with Vault through the castellan interface.  CyberArk would be presented through the same interface via the castellan library.
*are available* (?)
yes - will fix
probably the best one, especially in TLS-e env with freeIPA...

Why not make this the default? It's fine for most deployments, and deployments with more strict security requirements can opt-out of this and deploy Vault on a separate node instead. This would increase adoption considerably and increase the security of basic deployments.

We'll have to look into how vault can be deployed.  As I understand it, restarting vault requires unsealing the vault by N security officers providing credentials.  Unless there is a way to automatically provide the creds, this may be an unacceptable maintenance burden for deployers that do not have these security requirements.  

If we can restart automatically, then yeah, why not?
Yes, this has been an issue in Octavia deployments using Vault. Unsealing it can be an operational problem.
I don't see "vault" rpm in the standard repositories - does it mean we have to ship them in tripleo repos, meaning maintenance and so on?
typo
Ack

With services requiring a PKI to access Vault, what CA would be used to request the certs? Will IdM/FreeIPA be required to access Vault then? Will you use Vault as a CA (that would need a new certmonger plugin)? or will you use certmonger's self-signed certs and distribute the CA to be trusted to every node in the cluster?

I don't think we can get away from providing an option for deployers to provide their own certs.  There will be those that are required to use their corporate CA for instance, or that have an existing vault instance that they want to use.

The answer here must be beefed up validation to ensure that certs are valid and fully resolved.

We allow deployers to provide the CA certs and keys for Octavia. It has been a support challenge as many deployers do not understand how to use them. We have had deployers provide certs with non-matching keys, CAs they pull off of browsers without the intermediates, etc.
It would probably be best to not promote the "bring your own certs" in THT.
The more we can automate and/or do validation on, the better.

Maybe we can provide the following options (at least as MVP):

a) provide THT parameters to allow deployers to provide the CA cert/client cert.
b) provide option to use the IPA CA and certmonger to generate and manage the cert.
c) use app creds instead.

Using certmongers self signed certs feels hacky - particularly when we talking about then distributing the ca cert across nodes.

Is this just (secret-0)?  Maybe we can leverage Vault policy to do something fancier here?  For example, we could use one AppRole credential for TripleO to generate all the secrets and store them, and then use a different AppRole credential with read-only permissions to roll out to the Controller nodes for services to retrieve the secrets later.
Thats a great idea - a deployer appRole and a service appRole.  I'll mention this possibility in the next draft.

Hmm, so if one service gets compromised, all of the service secrets are exposed?
Wouldn't it be better to have per-service secret-0's?

There also has to be thought about how to trigger restarts when passwords change but the ref in the configuration file may not.  Today service restarts are based on file changes so if the password is no longer in the file and the reference is basically static, the service needs to be notified of to restart.

Good point.  If I recall correctly, castellan uses a random string when storing a password and does not have an option to update the password, which means that if it is changed, the reference is changed too.  We'd just need to make sure that the mapping file is also checked when determining if a service needs to be restarted.
that's an interesting option. We do not have such a way today to have changes ending up in hiera data at nodes omitting Heat (AFAIK). Would be nice to have it.
with the new task-core approach that could be simle jobs to run jq magic on target nodes.
...although I didn't fully get how that would save an overcloud deployment run, with or without some new THT parameters for hiera, since we'd have to apply changes to containers still somehow

Yes, I think an overcloud deployment run would still be needed.  The point above was just to point out that we could do that deployment without having to add a new THT Heat parameter for CastellanSecretRefs
typo
Ack
"What remains" - This confused me at first, I think this should be worder differently, since the passwords themselves also need to be rotated, like the following paragraphs state.

Maybe reword as: 

The only sensitive data that would remain on the nodes is the secret needed to retrieve the secrets from the secret store (secret-0).

Does that make more sense?

The secrets in the vaults would also need to be rotated with the rotation of the secret-0, right? Or maybe there is some auditing mechanism that could detect inexpedient access and alert the operator?

No, the rotation of secret-0 is independent of the rotation of the secrets in the vaults.

Think of it as storing a bunch of secrets in barbican.  When I change my keystone password, I can store still access the secrets I have previously stored.
I'm not sure I understand how this should work.  What sort of file would this custom script produce?

I was originally thinking that we needed to extract the secrets so that they could be stored again by the new secret store.  But this doesn't have to be a custom script.

We could add an option to tripleo-client to write the passwords in the deployment files - instead of just the references.  Then the procedure would be the following:

1. run tripleo-client and just generate the deployment files, using the option to write the 
   secrets in the deployment files.  This of course will be using the old secret store.
2. remove the references -- make sure to keep that list though so that the secrets can be
   purged from the vault later.
3. run an update with the existing deployment files and using the new secret store info.  This 
   should act like a non-secret-store to secret-store update.

this could be improved directly in castellan and the keystome middleware though, could it? Loading the secret the first time would for sure need to call Vault (or whatever secret store is being used), but then the secret could be kept in memory for quick and easy access. When eventually a rotation happens and keystone middleware returns an authentication error for the service, it could be programmed to try to re-fetch the credentials from castellan. This shouldn't be too problematic if `kernel.randomize_va_space` is enabled (and set to 2), since that provides *some* level of protection for the openstack processes to have the credentials in memory. This would also significantly reduce the traffic towards the Vault instance.
It looks like it might be a performance/security tradeoff in each instance, depending on what each service does with the secret. Some services might be able to use a hashed secret in runtime.
Would we need container images for Vault that we would need to build ourselves?

Is there any support in castellan for a "fake" backend? I'd like to have the ability to deploy with castellan, but make Vault optional.

In fact, that is a way that we could make castellan in the default path for all deployments, and just make the backend optional. Is there a plain text backend for castellan?

Yeah, we could do something like that.  I'll write a spec for castellan.  Of hand, I'd say we'd have something that would simply do something trivial and repeatable - like encrypt with a symmetric key.

So, store_secret() would just encrypt and base64 encode whatever was passed in and pass back this ciphertext as a "reference", and get_secret() would simply take the reference and decrypt it using the symmetric key.  generate_secret() would create a secret using os_get_random() and then encrypt and base64 encode the result and return it as a reference.

The secret-0 in this case is the symmetric key.

Does this depend on the oslo.config spec/work?
https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/oslo-specs/specs/stein/secret-management-store.html
are there any devstack jobs currently running with castellan, on barbican or any other repo?
Yes, we have vault jobs running for castellan and also in barbican.

Shouldn't just the lego and haproxy containers just share the same TLS related volume (mount or bind)?
Instead of doing this SSH transfer?
Containers aren't supposed to get new file injected during their lifecycle.

Only the let's encrypt container running on the FQDN will successfully retrieve certificates (since that is where the ACME request will be routed). Those certificates need to be distributed to the all the HAProxy nodes in the case that the VIP is changed. 

SSH is used to dynamically update the cert in HAproxy using the runtime API - https://www.haproxy.com/blog/dynamic-ssl-certificate-storage-in-haproxy/. 

The certificates are also transferred to the HAProxy nodes via SCP so that in the case of a container restart, the latest certificates are still used.

This is an exception to containers not having new files injected.

tobiko/shell/sh/_systemctl.py.message:
How should we call that function when we have multiple services to stop/start?

Because trying to call:
sh.stop_systemd_unit(' '.join(octavia.OCTAVIA_SERVICES),
                     ssh_client=ssh_client,
                     sudo=True)


Returns the same problem:
tobiko.shell.sh._exception.ShellCommandFailed: command 'sudo systemctl stop 'tripleo_octavia_worker.service tripleo_octavia_housekeeping.service tripleo_octavia_health_manager.service tripleo_octavia_api.service'' failed (exit status is 5);
stdin:
None
stdout:

stderr:
Invalid unit name "tripleo_octavia_worker.service tripleo_octavia_housekeeping.service tripleo_octavia_health_manager.service tripleo_octavia_api.service" was escaped as "tripleo_octavia_worker.service\x20tripleo_octavia_housekeeping.service\x20tripleo_octavia_health_manager.service\x20tripleo_octavia_api.service" (maybe you should use systemd-escape?)
Failed to stop tripleo_octavia_worker.service\x20tripleo_octavia_housekeeping.service\x20tripleo_octavia_health_manager.service\x20tripleo_octavia_api.service: Unit tripleo_octavia_worker.service\x20tripleo_octavia_housekeeping.service\x20tripleo_octavia_health_manager.service\x20tripleo_octavia_api.service not loaded.

We could call this method as below:

  sh.stop_systemd_unit(*units,
                       ssh_client=ssh_client,
                       sudo=True)

Where units is a list of strings.

Or we could continue calling it as below:
  sh.stop_systemd_unit(unit,
                       ssh_client=ssh_client,
                       sudo=True)

What wouldn't work anymore would be:
  sh.stop_systemd_unit(unit=unit,
                       ssh_client=ssh_client,
                       sudo=True)

This is needed due neutron, keystone and rabbitmq port variables not being in line with other services e.g. "keystone_public_port", "neutron_server_port" and "rabbitmq_port".

You could argue that rabbitmq is not an openstack service, but it is fundamental to a working system and is something that as an operator I'd want being monitored out the box.

most openstack services have their port variables named like so {{some service}}_api_port

I would like to come up with a better solution for handling the edge case ports like "swift_object_server_port". Open to suggestions.

test/unit/proxy/test_server.py.message:
oh gosh, so the error is like a keep alive for the error counter.

I wonder if the goal was “error limit errors in suppression interval suppresses requests for suppression interval” and it’s just a bug?  that’s always how I thought it worked and don’t understand why it doesn’t.

I've got this gut feeling like we need to move away from this notion that a node is either error-limited or it's not -- what I kind of want is something where we try to estimate the probability that a request to a node is going to error and use that to inform whether we make a particular request or not.

Something like https://paste.opendev.org/show/bj5m3lXImDLiX5tp4Bvu/ but

* have those 0.5 and 0.001 constants be configurable and
* consider whether we want the simple P(make request) := 1 - P(request will error) that I implemented or something more complicated

It also occurs to me that we may want to distinguish between a congestion-related error (timeout, 529) and other server errors. I'm not convinced that a 500 on one request means the next request to that node is particularly likely to 500 -- it was more likely due to the particular request that was made.

We probably also ought to distinguish between 507-unmounted and 507-disk full -- it 100% makes sense to immediately stop sending any requests to a currently-unmounted drive, or to stop sending *writes* to a full drive. *Reads*, on the other hand, are a more complicated story...

I don't know the history of the retry count, but I agree that a job that may need 5 retries should be experimental at best, in particular if each attempt may take 2 hours.
Should backport is potentially == should also forward port.

It applies to the pre playbook and it applies to the whole job if ansible determines that the failure was due to network connectivity issues. In this case the job appears to be taking about an hour to fill up its disk then fail due to "network conenctivity issues" because ansible can't write its remote scripts to tmp dirs:

  TASK [remove-build-sshkey : Remove the build SSH key from all nodes]

  primary |     prefix, suffix, dir, output_type = _sanitize_params(prefix, suffix, dir)
  primary |   File "/usr/lib64/python3.6/tempfile.py", line 130, in _sanitize_params

  primary | FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] No usable temporary directory found in ['/tmp', '/var/tmp', '/usr/tmp', '/home/zuul']
  primary | ERROR: Ignoring Errors

My concern is that you're setting it globally for all of your jobs and it is problemtic on jobs like this. Instead of setting it globally you should set it in a targetted fashion while addressing problems rather than simply accepting 5 retries is ok. For example in this case I imagine that filling the disk is fairly determinstic and you're hitting the luck of the draw on which cloud (and consequently node flavor) you end up with. The solution here is not to retry 5 times blindly it is to fix the job.

Hmm, at some point we were told that retries apply only to the pre playbook which sets up the stage. In that case, the 5 retries are reasonable. If it applies to the entire job, then it does not make sense at all. Please clarify.

- evaluate the expression
- if RecurseError is thown, double the the current limit and try again,

I think this is overkill.  AFAIK the default is 1000 on any platform of interest for us, but the way the code is written, it doesn't actually matter what the default is.

The container has to be buikd and run as rootless. So that we don't create a security hole.

For the container file, imho keeping the file into the script is better for few reasons.
The main reason for me is that we dont have to take care of the presence of the file, the path, where it's located and also to avoid breach where the user or someone modify the Containerfile and then break the build.
Also, since it's a dynamic file, I dont see much objection to dump it dynamicaly from a string to the file system. It's simply a dynamic string that we move into a container file.

neutron_taas/services/taas/service_drive.message:
Here we are changing the message format on the wire. Which leads to an rpc upgrade issue. For example when the server is upgraded but the agent is not yet, we'll get something like:

 ERROR oslo_messaging.rpc.server TypeError: create_tap_service() got an unexpected keyword argument 'tap_service_msg'

We either need to leave the wire-format unchanged, or bump the rpc version and handle the version upgrade gracefully. I believe the code refactor you proposed here can work without changing the wire-format.

neutronclient/osc/v2/dynamic_routing/pee.message:
I see that in the spec we turned the association objects into first class objects, but only halfway. They have (globally unique) IDs (and not unique names), but still they cannot be operated on without a reference to the bgp speaker. Which was probably a mistake (and unfortunately the same mistake we made with qos policy rules before), but I don't suggest we change the spec now.

However here I recommend that we stick to the same order as we have in the url and (mostly) in the cli command words:

openstack bgp speaker peer association list SPEAKER
openstack bgp speaker peer association show SPEAKER ASSOCIATION-NAME-OR-ID
openstack bgp speaker peer association create SPEAKER ASSOCIATION-NAME PEER (*)
openstack bgp speaker peer association delete SPEAKER ASSOCIATION-NAME-OR-ID

This clearly violates multiple user expectations and osc conventions:

1) The user would expect the globally unique id of an association to be sufficient in identifying the association.
2) osc only uses multiple positional parameters for nameless associations (like router add subnet).
3) osc uses only one positional parameter for operations on named objects, which is always the name.
*) This one is particularly confusing because we don't use "associate" in the verb form (bgp speaker associate peer), so we have speaker-peer-association order in the command words and speaker-association-peer order in the arguments. But this kind of depends on whether the user reads the command as "bgp speaker peer-association" or "bgp speaker peer association".

Despite these problems I don't really see a better cli syntax. We may have an alternative (of which I don't know if it's better) if we completely drop the name attribute of the association (both client and server side). Then we could do this:

openstack bgp speaker peer association list SPEAKER
openstack bgp speaker peer association show SPEAKER [--association ASSOCIATION | --peer PEER]
openstack bgp speaker peer association create SPEAKER --peer PEER
openstack bgp speaker peer association delete SPEAKER [--association ASSOCIATION | --peer PEER]

Which could be simplified to:

openstack bgp speaker peer association list SPEAKER
openstack bgp speaker peer association show SPEAKER ASSOCIATION
openstack bgp speaker peer association create SPEAKER PEER
openstack bgp speaker peer association delete SPEAKER ASSOCIATION

Whichever we do it may be worth to also compare the syntax to 'openstack network qos rule' operations.

There are a few problems which I found for using association objects as a complete first class objects.
1. Similar associations objects(router/peer) are used in networking-bgpvpn also. So it was not sure how to make the router/peer association unique for n-d-r.
2. the url needs both speaker id and association id since speaker is parent of peer association. So, it was not clear whether any options were there to discard speaker-id while using it from client.

And regarding the order of arguments, the suggestion of bringing speaker before association looks better and clear. 

In the current patch , I used the approach followed in networking-bgpvpn (SPEAKER comes after ASSOCIATION-NAME-OR-ID). Not sure why this order is being used there. 

Can I go ahead with the below change?
openstack bgp speaker peer association list SPEAKER
openstack bgp speaker peer association show SPEAKER ASSOCIATION-NAME-OR-ID
openstack bgp speaker peer association create SPEAKER ASSOCIATION-NAME PEER (*)
openstack bgp speaker peer association delete SPEAKER ASSOCIATION-NAME-OR-ID
Main difference from the current patch would be that SPEAKER comes before ASSOCIATION-NAME

/COMMIT_MSG.message: I concerned thing is that whether this result in the qg- port lose link-local address?

it shouldn't result in qg-port lose link-local address as this option is only about how it's being generated:

```
addr_gen_mode - INTEGER
	Defines how link-local and autoconf addresses are generated.

	0: generate address based on EUI64 (default)
	1: do no generate a link-local address, use EUI64 for addresses generated
	   from autoconf
	2: generate stable privacy addresses, using the secret from
	   stable_secret (RFC7217)
	3: generate stable privacy addresses, using a random secret if unset
```

so if You assign link-local address manually(keepalived does that in our case) it won't be flushed later by this option.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Since we are changing code that affects extend and disconnect volume... is there a risk of anything happening when nova-compute is upgraded to use this version of os-brick, without detaching volumes that are currently in use?

I took that into consideration when writing the code, so besides the risk that I inadvertently introduced a bug I don't think it'd be a problem.

The reason is that the `connect_volume_undo_prepare_result` method uses the `_device_path_from_symlink` method to replace the symlink with the one that the connector originally returned, and that method explicitly looks for the custom symlink format (which is impossible to have been used by any of the existing connections) and if it doesn't match then it leaves the path as it was.

That way existing encrypted connections will not have their paths modified.  The only difference will be that they get a copy of the dictionary instead of the original one.

In any case, your concern is so important that I'm going to harden it a bit more so that in those cases **nothing** changes.
